entry.value: This page features different methods on how to do the basic data copy within Rapid.

Let's begin with something simple to get you introduced to data copying. Copying between input boxes is the simplest, and most common, form of data copying. Data entered in the first input box will be copied into the second input box below it. After you have typed something, click out of the input box and see what happens.
With data copying between input boxes introduced, let's go further and data copy from a dropdown list into an input box.
[{"text":"Please select...","value":""},{"text":"Sample value 1","value":"Sample value 1"},{"text":"Sample value 2","value":"Sample value 2"},{"text":"Sample value 3","value":"Sample value 3"}]

Still simple isn't it? Things start to get a little more interesting when we introduce codes into our dropdown. When using codes and data copying, the codes will be stored instead of our actual values.
Keeping up so far? Now let's work on populating our dropdown list with values from an input box. These values will be entered as available options inside of our dropdown list.
alert("Your input should not be blank");

Moving on to something more complicated, it is possible to use the values in a dropdown list to populate another dropdown list. In this example we will be using codes, so the codes will appear in our second dropdown list.
With dropdown lists covered we are now going to move on to radio buttons. These are very similar to checkboxes, with the exception of a value being required.

Here we will be doing the same as above, however we will be including codes with our radio buttons this time. Whenever codes and data copies are concerned the code will always be pulled through, as opposed to the text values.

Checkboxes handle data differently to radio buttons, despite their similarity. Data copied through is in relation to whether the box is ticked or unticked, meaning it will always have some value attached to it.

Moving on from checkboxes, the date control is able to copy in both the current date and work out a person's age based on today's date. For this data copy we will be copying both the date and the age.

Finally we are going to cover the score control, a newer entry into Rapid's extensive control library. Similar to dropdowns, the score control will copy in the value or the code, if used, directly into other fields.

[{"style":"max-width: 400px;","controlId":"P5_C10_","text":"Getting used to data copying in this simple way is a great stepping stone, and introduction to further testing and experimentation with data copying. As you may have guessed by now, it is possible to data copy between many different controls in Rapid, with input boxes being the simplest. Not all controls store the same type of data, so it is worth bearing that in mind.","type":"hover"},{"style":"max-width: 400px;","controlId":"P5_C44_","text":"This type of data copying can be used in conjunction with a datastore in order to store this information on the current page and display it at a later point for review or reference.","type":"hover"},{"style":"max-width: 400px;","controlId":"P5_C43_","text":"This may seem like it is not very useful, but there are times when this functionality is exactly what we need. A good example would be on a Rapid form application where we require certain information under one name, but use the code behind it for another purpose.","type":"hover"},{"style":"max-width: 400px;","controlId":"P5_C50_","text":"For this data copy we have used the bulk data copy. This is a powerful version of the data copy action that allows us to perform multiple data copies in the same action. In this use it isn't exactly needed, however it is brilliant for saving a room in your Rapid application. More information on bulk data copies is covered on our Youtube tutorial video for making a desktop app, which you can access by clicking on this hint. There is also a logic action tied to this, however those will be covered on another page","type":"hover"},{"style":"max-width: 400px;","controlId":"P5_C63_","text":"As mentioned before in another hint, copying codes across can be a useful thing to data copy. It can be especially useful when matching keys in databases. Although this data copy will continue to copy in the values, even if they have already done so once before, it is possible to code a check for this, however for this example we are not worried about that.","type":"hover"},{"style":"max-width: 400px;","controlId":"P5_C80_","text":"Radio buttons are interesting as they always have to be a value, they cannot be without one. This is what sets them apart from checkboxes. In this example we are only copying over the text of the radio button.","type":"hover"},{"style":"max-width: 400px;","controlId":"P5_C89_","text":"In this example we are copying over the radio button codes. As mentioned in a previous hint, this can be useful when matching data in a database when a value must be provided, such as gender.","type":"hover"},{"style":"max-width: 400px;","controlId":"P5_C99_","text":"As you can see when ticking the box, the value of whether the box is checked or not is pulled through, rather than what the label is. This can be useful when checking if a value is true or false in your form, or for when the question relates to a database.","type":"hover"},{"style":"max-width: 400px;","controlId":"P5_C111_","text":"As dates can be formatted in a variety of different ways it is very versatile to work with when copying over the entered date, and works especially well with databases that may only take in dates in a particular format. For this data copy we will once again be making use of the bulk data copy. Clicking this hint will lead you to our Youtube video, which provides more information on this.","type":"hover"},{"style":"max-width: 400px;","controlId":"P5_C134_","text":"As the score control is relatively new to Rapid it has yet to have it's full potential realised. This control can be very useful on apps that have the option to rate something. Scores can be a range of numbers to letters, and the codes behind the score can be a more detailed analysis of the option selected. More information on the score controls is included in a Rapid tutorial video on making a desktop application. Click the hint to follow the link.","type":"hover"}]

{"controlHints":[{"style":"max-width: 400px;","controlId":"P5_C10_","text":"Getting used to data copying in this simple way is a great stepping stone, and introduction to further testing and experimentation with data copying. As you may have guessed by now, it is possible to data copy between many different controls in Rapid, with input boxes being the simplest. Not all controls store the same type of data, so it is worth bearing that in mind.","type":"hover"},{"style":"max-width: 400px;","controlId":"P5_C44_","text":"This type of data copying can be used in conjunction with a datastore in order to store this information on the current page and display it at a later point for review or reference.","type":"hover"},{"style":"max-width: 400px;","controlId":"P5_C43_","text":"This may seem like it is not very useful, but there are times when this functionality is exactly what we need. A good example would be on a Rapid form application where we require certain information under one name, but use the code behind it for another purpose.","type":"hover"},{"style":"max-width: 400px;","controlId":"P5_C50_","text":"For this data copy we have used the bulk data copy. This is a powerful version of the data copy action that allows us to perform multiple data copies in the same action. In this use it isn't exactly needed, however it is brilliant for saving a room in your Rapid application. More information on bulk data copies is covered on our Youtube tutorial video for making a desktop app, which you can access by clicking on this hint. There is also a logic action tied to this, however those will be covered on another page","type":"hover"},{"style":"max-width: 400px;","controlId":"P5_C63_","text":"As mentioned before in another hint, copying codes across can be a useful thing to data copy. It can be especially useful when matching keys in databases. Although this data copy will continue to copy in the values, even if they have already done so once before, it is possible to code a check for this, however for this example we are not worried about that.","type":"hover"},{"style":"max-width: 400px;","controlId":"P5_C80_","text":"Radio buttons are interesting as they always have to be a value, they cannot be without one. This is what sets them apart from checkboxes. In this example we are only copying over the text of the radio button.","type":"hover"},{"style":"max-width: 400px;","controlId":"P5_C89_","text":"In this example we are copying over the radio button codes. As mentioned in a previous hint, this can be useful when matching data in a database when a value must be provided, such as gender.","type":"hover"},{"style":"max-width: 400px;","controlId":"P5_C99_","text":"As you can see when ticking the box, the value of whether the box is checked or not is pulled through, rather than what the label is. This can be useful when checking if a value is true or false in your form, or for when the question relates to a database.","type":"hover"},{"style":"max-width: 400px;","controlId":"P5_C111_","text":"As dates can be formatted in a variety of different ways it is very versatile to work with when copying over the entered date, and works especially well with databases that may only take in dates in a particular format. For this data copy we will once again be making use of the bulk data copy. Clicking this hint will lead you to our Youtube video, which provides more information on this.","type":"hover"},{"style":"max-width: 400px;","controlId":"P5_C134_","text":"As the score control is relatively new to Rapid it has yet to have it's full potential realised. This control can be very useful on apps that have the option to rate something. Scores can be a range of numbers to letters, and the codes behind the score can be a more detailed analysis of the option selected. More information on the score controls is included in a Rapid tutorial video on making a desktop application. Click the hint to follow the link.","type":"hover"}]}

page.htmlBody:
This page features different methods on how to do the basic data copy within Rapid.

Let's begin with something simple to get you introduced to data copying. Copying between input boxes is the simplest, and most common, form of data copying. Data entered in the first input box will be copied into the second input box below it. After you have typed something, click out of the input box and see what happens.
With data copying between input boxes introduced, let's go further and data copy from a dropdown list into an input box.
Still simple isn't it? Things start to get a little more interesting when we introduce codes into our dropdown. When using codes and data copying, the codes will be stored instead of our actual values.
Keeping up so far? Now let's work on populating our dropdown list with values from an input box. These values will be entered as available options inside of our dropdown list.
Moving on to something more complicated, it is possible to use the values in a dropdown list to populate another dropdown list. In this example we will be using codes, so the codes will appear in our second dropdown list.
With dropdown lists covered we are now going to move on to radio buttons. These are very similar to checkboxes, with the exception of a value being required.
Here we will be doing the same as above, however we will be including codes with our radio buttons this time. Whenever codes and data copies are concerned the code will always be pulled through, as opposed to the text values.
Checkboxes handle data differently to radio buttons, despite their similarity. Data copied through is in relation to whether the box is ticked or unticked, meaning it will always have some value attached to it.
Moving on from checkboxes, the date control is able to copy in both the current date and work out a person's age based on today's date. For this data copy we will be copying both the date and the age.
Finally we are going to cover the score control, a newer entry into Rapid's extensive control library. Similar to dropdowns, the score control will copy in the value or the code, if used, directly into other fields.
ABCDE
page.name: 03_dataCopies

rolesHtml.html:
This page features different methods on how to do the basic data copy within Rapid.

Let's begin with something simple to get you introduced to data copying. Copying between input boxes is the simplest, and most common, form of data copying. Data entered in the first input box will be copied into the second input box below it. After you have typed something, click out of the input box and see what happens.
With data copying between input boxes introduced, let's go further and data copy from a dropdown list into an input box.
Still simple isn't it? Things start to get a little more interesting when we introduce codes into our dropdown. When using codes and data copying, the codes will be stored instead of our actual values.
Keeping up so far? Now let's work on populating our dropdown list with values from an input box. These values will be entered as available options inside of our dropdown list.
Moving on to something more complicated, it is possible to use the values in a dropdown list to populate another dropdown list. In this example we will be using codes, so the codes will appear in our second dropdown list.
With dropdown lists covered we are now going to move on to radio buttons. These are very similar to checkboxes, with the exception of a value being required.
Here we will be doing the same as above, however we will be including codes with our radio buttons this time. Whenever codes and data copies are concerned the code will always be pulled through, as opposed to the text values.
Checkboxes handle data differently to radio buttons, despite their similarity. Data copied through is in relation to whether the box is ticked or unticked, meaning it will always have some value attached to it.
Moving on from checkboxes, the date control is able to copy in both the current date and work out a person's age based on today's date. For this data copy we will be copying both the date and the age.
Finally we are going to cover the score control, a newer entry into Rapid's extensive control library. Similar to dropdowns, the score control will copy in the value or the code, if used, directly into other fields.
ABCDE

page.title: Data copy details
